newsitem.title: GERMANY: Reuters German Advertising & Media Digest -June 24.
newsitem.headline: Reuters German Advertising & Media Digest -June 24.

text.p: REUTERS GERMAN ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST
News from Reuters and the German press on Advertising,
Marketing, Media, the Internet, Brand-name Products and
Consumer Trends
ADVERTISING & MARKETING:
BERLIN - Commercial TV channel Sat.1 rejects a magazine report
claiming that it would faces millions of marks in fines for
showing too many commercials during its airtime. The company
says allegations of excessive advertising were made years ago
and that media authorities have not come to a decision on the
issue. The statement follows a report in the news magazine Focus
that Sat.1 faced 15.8 million marks ($9.2 million) in fines.
(Reuter)
FRANKFURT - Hamburg-based agency Springer & Jacoby wins
multi-million-mark account with confectionery manufacturer van
Melle, Detmold to help create new markets for its products.
(Horizont)
MAINZ - German public TV station ZDF says it plans to launch a
new programme and new image in August. Last year ZDF spent 8.2
million marks on programme promotion. (Reuter)
MEDIA & THE INTERNET:
MUNICH - The Kirch Group is holding talks with France's
Canal-Plus about the German and the Italian pay-TV markets,
according to a Kirch spokesman. Kirch and Bertelsmann affiliate
CLT-UFA announced they planned to operate German pay-TV
broadcaster Premiere as a 50-50 venture. A joint statement said
Canal-Plus, which holds 37.5 percent of Premiere, was satisfied
with the deal. Canal-Plus declined to comment.
(Reuter)
MUNICH - ProSieben Media AG offers investors the prospect of a
relatively cheap entry into Germany's media sector by saying new
shares in the commercial TV channel would cost no more than 72
marks. Following weeks of a high-profile media campaign modelled
after the hugely successful marketing blitz of phone giant
Deutsche Telekom, ProSieben says the price for its shares will
be set through a bookbuilding phase at between 66-72 marks. The
final offer price for the 17.5 million non-voting preference
shares will be set over the next two weeks. Share trade begins
on July 7. (Reuter)
FRANKFURT - Online-Dienst Germany.Net, the free-to-use Internet
service, says it is receiving 500 new registrations daily and
has a total of 200,000 clients. (Reuter)
BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS & MARKETS:
FRANKFURT - The German tobacco industry says it does not expect
any direct implications from the multi-billion-dollar U.S.
settlement reached on June 20. The German Cigarette
Manufacturers Federation says the deal was a result of
characteristics of the U.S. legal system which contrast sharply
to legal conditions across Europe. (Frankfurter Allgemeine
Zeitung)
MUNICH - Joachim Prinz is named management board chairman of
computer distributor Computer 2000 Deutschland, taking over from
Karl Pohler. Prinz will also be in charge of marketing
activities for the group. (Reuter)
FRANKFURT - Adidas AG is a favourite to join the German 30-share
DAX index and replace struggling retailer Karstadt AG, according
to financial analysts. Adidas, the sportswear firm with the
legendary three-stripe logo, is considered a top candidate to be
chosen for the blue-chip index next month because it is among
the top 35 German shares in terms of trading volume and market
capitalisation. (Reuter)
PEOPLE NEWS:
MUNICH - Josef Andorfer, 40, is to be new business manager at
the private TV station RTL2. He's scheduled to take over from
Rudolf-Markus Reischl on August 1. (Sueddeutsche Zeitung)
HAMBURG - Bagher Pirouz, Michael Weigert and Ewald Wolf are to
leave Scholz & Friends to set up their own agency, the
advertising agency says. (Reuter)
HAMBURG - Peter John Mahrenholz, head of strategy for Hamburg ad
agency Jung von Matt, is to be replaced by Andreas Mengele of
Scholz & Friends. Mahrenholz is to take charge of the
newly-created agency Pentagon Network Marketing GmbH. (Reuter)
